questions.stem: A family therapist observes that a mother and her 12-year-old son share an extremely close relationship, frequently finish each other's sentences, and the mother reports knowing 'everything' about the child's inner life. The father appears disengaged and uninvolved. According to Minuchin's structural model, the mother-son subsystem is BEST described as:

options.text: Differentiated
Enmeshed
Disengaged
Triangulated

questions.explanation: In Minuchin's structural family therapy, enmeshment refers to diffuse, overly permeable boundaries between subsystem members, resulting in excessive closeness and loss of individual autonomy. The mother-son dyad shows hallmarks of enmeshment: extreme closeness, mind-reading, and blurred boundaries. The father's disengagement represents the opposite pole — rigid boundaries with emotional distance. Healthy families have clear (neither enmeshed nor disengaged) boundaries.

questions.stem: In Bowen's family systems theory, when a married couple experiencing marital conflict focuses excessively on their child's behavior problems to reduce their own tension, this pattern is BEST described as:

options.text: Emotional cutoff
Triangulation
Multigenerational transmission
Nuclear family emotional process

questions.explanation: Triangulation occurs when a two-person relationship under stress pulls in a third person to stabilize the dyad. The parents reduce their marital tension by focusing on the child, who becomes the stabilizing third point of the triangle. Bowen considered triangles the basic unit of relationship systems. Emotional cutoff involves reducing contact with family; multigenerational transmission involves patterns across generations; the nuclear family emotional system describes four patterns of anxiety management (of which impairment in children is one).

questions.stem: A strategic family therapist instructs a couple who argues every evening to schedule their arguments for exactly 8:00 PM and argue for exactly 30 minutes. This intervention is BEST classified as:

options.text: Reframing
Enactment
Paradoxical intervention (prescribing the symptom)
Boundary making

questions.explanation: Prescribing the symptom is a paradoxical intervention associated with strategic family therapy (Haley, Madanes, MRI group). By directing the couple to deliberately engage in the problematic behavior at a specific time, the symptom becomes voluntary rather than involuntary. If the couple complies, they gain control over the behavior; if they resist the directive, they stop arguing. Either outcome disrupts the symptom pattern. Reframing changes the meaning of behavior; enactment has family members interact in session; boundary making adjusts subsystem permeability.

questions.stem: A narrative therapist asks a family, 'When did Anger first start taking over your dinnertime? Are there evenings when your family has successfully stood up to Anger and not let it ruin the meal?' This technique is BEST identified as:

options.text: Circular questioning
Externalization combined with searching for unique outcomes
Reframing the presenting problem
Solution-focused exception finding

questions.explanation: This is a hallmark narrative therapy intervention combining two core techniques: externalization (personifying 'Anger' as a separate entity that acts upon the family rather than as a trait of any family member) and searching for unique outcomes (identifying times when the problem did not dominate — evenings when Anger did not take over). While similar to SFBT exception questions, the language of externalization ('stood up to Anger') is distinctly narrative therapy. Circular questioning (Milan) asks one member about relationships between others.

questions.stem: In the Milan systemic approach, a therapist asks the daughter, 'Who do you think is most affected when your parents argue — your brother or your grandmother?' This intervention is BEST identified as:

options.text: Enactment
Circular questioning
Externalization
Genogram construction

questions.explanation: Circular questioning, developed by the Milan group (Selvini Palazzoli, Boscolo, Cecchin, Prata), involves asking one family member to comment on the relationship or reactions of other family members. This reveals systemic patterns, alliances, and perceptions that direct questioning cannot access. Enactment (Minuchin) asks members to interact with each other in session; externalization (narrative therapy) separates the problem from the person; genograms (Bowen) map multigenerational family patterns.

questions.stem: Which of the following are core techniques specifically associated with Minuchin's structural family therapy? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Joining — accommodating to the family's style to build rapport before attempting change
Enactment — asking family members to interact with each other in session so patterns can be observed
Externalization — linguistically separating the problem from the person's identity
Unbalancing — deliberately siding with one family member to shift the power structure
Circular questioning — asking one member to comment on relationships between other members

questions.explanation: Joining, enactment, and unbalancing are signature techniques of Minuchin's structural family therapy. Joining establishes rapport; enactment reveals actual interaction patterns; unbalancing disrupts dysfunctional hierarchies. Externalization belongs to narrative therapy (White & Epston), and circular questioning belongs to the Milan systemic approach (Selvini Palazzoli et al.).

questions.stem: According to Bowen's family systems theory, which of the following are correctly identified as core theoretical concepts? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Differentiation of self — the ability to maintain one's own sense of self while in emotional contact with others
Multigenerational transmission process — emotional patterns transmitted across generations
Emotional cutoff — reducing contact with family to manage unresolved attachment
Positive connotation — reframing each member's behavior as serving a protective function
Ordeal therapy — assigning tasks more difficult than the symptom to make it not worth maintaining

questions.explanation: Differentiation of self, multigenerational transmission, and emotional cutoff are all core Bowenian concepts. Bowen also identified triangulation, the nuclear family emotional system, family projection process, sibling position, and societal emotional process. Positive connotation belongs to the Milan systemic approach, and ordeal therapy belongs to strategic family therapy (Haley).

questions.stem: Which of the following accurately describe key principles of narrative therapy as developed by White and Epston? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The person is not the problem; the problem is the problem
The therapist adopts a decentered but influential therapeutic stance
Narrative therapy is grounded in social constructionist epistemology and influenced by Foucault's power/knowledge framework
The therapist serves as the expert authority who interprets the client's narrative and provides corrective insights
Treatment focuses primarily on restructuring maladaptive cognitive schemas through Socratic questioning

questions.explanation: Narrative therapy's foundational axiom is 'the person is not the problem; the problem is the problem.' The therapist adopts a decentered (not the expert on the client's life) but influential (actively facilitative) stance. The approach is grounded in social constructionism and Foucault's analysis of power/knowledge. The therapist does not serve as an expert authority (that contradicts the decentered stance) and does not use cognitive restructuring (that is CBT).

questions.stem: Which of the following are correctly identified as Satir's four dysfunctional communication stances? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Placator — agrees with everything to avoid conflict and ignores own needs
Blamer — finds fault with others, aggressive and dominating
Super-reasonable (computer) — intellectualizes and detaches from feelings
Congruent communicator — expresses feelings directly and honestly while respecting others
Irrelevant (distracter) — changes the subject and uses humor to deflect

questions.explanation: Satir identified four dysfunctional communication stances adopted under stress: placator, blamer, super-reasonable (computer), and irrelevant (distracter). The congruent communicator is not a dysfunctional stance — it is the healthy alternative that Satir considered the goal of therapy, where the person expresses feelings directly and honestly while respecting others.

questions.stem: Which of the following are fundamental principles of general systems theory as applied to family therapy? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Circular causality — behavior in families is mutually influenced rather than following a linear cause-effect chain
Homeostasis — families tend to maintain stability and resist change, with symptoms potentially serving a system-balancing function
Linear determinism — the identified patient's symptoms are caused by a single identifiable traumatic event
Equifinality — different initial conditions can lead to the same outcome in a family system
Individual pathology — psychological problems reside solely within the identified patient and are independent of family context

questions.explanation: Circular causality, homeostasis, and equifinality are core systems theory concepts. Circular causality replaces linear cause-effect thinking with mutual influence; homeostasis explains the system's tendency toward stability; equifinality recognizes multiple pathways to the same outcome. Linear determinism and individual pathology contradict the fundamental systemic perspective that views problems as embedded in relational patterns rather than residing within a single individual.

questions.stem: Match each family therapy approach to its primary developer(s).
questions.explanation: Structural family therapy was developed by Salvador Minuchin, focusing on family structure, boundaries, and hierarchies. Strategic family therapy was developed by Jay Haley (and Cloe Madanes), emphasizing directives and paradoxical interventions. Bowenian family systems therapy was developed by Murray Bowen, centering on differentiation of self and multigenerational patterns. Narrative therapy was developed by Michael White and David Epston, using externalization and re-authoring of life stories.

questions.stem: Match each therapeutic technique to the family therapy approach it is MOST strongly associated with.
questions.explanation: Genograms (multigenerational family diagrams) are associated with Bowenian therapy for mapping emotional patterns across at least three generations. Paradoxical interventions are associated with strategic therapy (Haley) — prescribing the symptom to make it voluntary and therefore controllable. Family sculpting is associated with Satir's experiential approach — physically positioning family members to represent relational dynamics. Externalization is the signature technique of narrative therapy (White & Epston) — separating the problem from the person's identity.

questions.stem: For each family therapy concept, select ALL approaches in which it plays a central role. Some concepts are shared across approaches.
questions.explanation: Boundaries (enmeshed/disengaged/clear) are central to Minuchin's structural approach. Reframing is used in both strategic therapy (Haley) and the Milan approach (positive connotation is a form of reframing). Directives and homework are central to strategic therapy (Haley's hallmark) and the Milan approach (invariant prescriptions and rituals). Multigenerational patterns are uniquely central to Bowenian therapy (multigenerational transmission process, genograms).

questions.stem: For each family therapy concept, select ALL descriptions that correctly apply. Multiple descriptions may apply to each concept.

columns.text: Involves surface-level modifications within the existing system structure
The family member presented as 'the problem' whose symptoms reflect system dysfunction
The family's tendency to maintain stability and resist change
A fundamental transformation of the system's structure or rules

questions.explanation: The identified patient (IP) is the family member labeled as having the problem, but systemic therapists view the IP's symptoms as reflecting dysfunction in the larger system. Homeostasis is the system's tendency to maintain stability and resist change, with symptoms potentially serving a stabilizing function. First-order change involves surface-level adjustments within the existing structure (e.g., changing who enforces rules but not the dysfunctional pattern). Second-order change involves fundamental structural transformation (e.g., reorganizing the family hierarchy entirely). Most family therapies aim for second-order change.

questions.stem: In structural family therapy, {{blank1}} refers to the therapist's initial accommodation to the family's style before attempting change. When a parent and child form an alliance against the other parent, crossing generational lines, this is called a {{blank2}}. The technique of asking family members to interact with each other in session rather than talking to the therapist is called {{blank3}}. In Bowen's theory, the capacity to maintain one's sense of self while in emotional contact with others is called {{blank4}}.

options.text: Joining
Enactment
Unbalancing
Restructuring
Coalition
Subsystem
Triangle
Enmeshment
Enactment
Joining
Circular questioning
Family sculpting
Differentiation of self
Emotional cutoff
Individuation
Self-actualization

questions.explanation: Joining is the structural therapist's initial process of accommodating to the family system. A coalition is a cross-generational alliance (parent-child against the other parent), which is dysfunctional because it violates the generational hierarchy. Enactment asks family members to demonstrate their interaction patterns in session. Differentiation of self (Bowen) is the capacity to maintain individuality while remaining emotionally connected — distinguishing it from emotional cutoff (reducing contact) and individuation (a developmental concept).

questions.stem: The Milan group developed {{blank1}} as a technique where one family member is asked to comment on the relationship between two other family members. In narrative therapy, the signature technique of linguistically separating the problem from the person's identity is called {{blank2}}. The MRI group's key concept is that problems are maintained by the very {{blank3}} people use to try to resolve them. Virginia Satir identified four dysfunctional communication stances, with the healthy alternative being the {{blank4}}.

options.text: Circular questioning
Linear questioning
Paradoxical questioning
Strategic questioning
Externalization
Re-authoring
Deconstruction
Reframing
Attempted solutions
Defense mechanisms
Communication patterns
Family rules
Congruent communicator
Super-reasonable communicator
Assertive communicator
Differentiated communicator

questions.explanation: Circular questioning (Milan group) reveals systemic patterns by having one member comment on other members' relationships. Externalization (narrative therapy) is the signature technique of separating the problem from the person. The MRI (Mental Research Institute) group's central concept is that attempted solutions maintain problems — therapy interrupts failed solution cycles. Satir's four dysfunctional stances (placator, blamer, super-reasonable, irrelevant) contrast with the congruent communicator, who expresses feelings directly and honestly.

questions.stem: A family presents to therapy with their 15-year-old daughter as the identified patient for 'oppositional behavior.' The structural family therapist observes that the mother and daughter are extremely close (sharing secrets, the daughter sleeping in the mother's room), while the father is emotionally distant and uninvolved. The parents rarely communicate directly and instead relay messages through the daughter. Analyze the systemic dynamics.

options.text: Enmeshed mother-daughter subsystem with diffuse boundaries and excessive closeness
Cross-generational coalition between mother and daughter that excludes the father and undermines the parental hierarchy
The daughter has an oppositional defiant disorder that is the primary cause of the family's dysfunction
The father's disengagement is an independent personality trait unrelated to the family system
Dysfunctional family structure with boundary violations and disrupted hierarchy requiring structural reorganization
Individual psychopathology in the daughter requiring individual CBT for oppositional behavior
Normal adolescent rebellion that will resolve without intervention
Strengthen the parental subsystem boundary by bringing the parents together as a collaborative team
Create age-appropriate distance in the mother-daughter subsystem and draw the father back into the family
Focus exclusively on the daughter's oppositional behavior through individual behavior modification
Advise the mother to completely sever her close relationship with her daughter

questions.explanation: From a structural perspective, the daughter's 'oppositional behavior' reflects dysfunctional family structure rather than individual pathology. The enmeshed mother-daughter relationship with its diffuse boundaries and the cross-generational coalition (mother-daughter against father) have disrupted the parental hierarchy. The structural therapist would work to strengthen the parental subsystem, create clear (not rigid) boundaries in the mother-daughter relationship, and re-engage the father — reorganizing the family's structure rather than treating the daughter individually.

questions.stem: A couple presents for therapy reporting chronic conflict. The Bowenian therapist constructs a genogram and discovers that both spouses come from families with high levels of emotional reactivity, that the wife's mother had a pattern of emotional cutoff from her own family of origin, and that the husband's father managed anxiety through alcohol. The therapist notes that the couple frequently triangulates their 8-year-old son. Analyze using Bowenian concepts.

options.text: Multigenerational transmission of low differentiation and emotional reactivity patterns from both families of origin
Triangulation of the son to stabilize the marital dyad's anxiety, with the child absorbing the couple's unresolved tension
The couple's problems are caused entirely by current stressors and have no connection to their families of origin
The son's involvement is a healthy sign of family cohesion and shared problem-solving
Low differentiation of self in both spouses, perpetuating multigenerational emotional patterns
Communication skills deficit requiring psychoeducation about active listening
Structural boundary violations requiring immediate subsystem reorganization
Increase each spouse's differentiation by helping them examine their own emotional reactivity and family-of-origin patterns
Detriangulate the son by helping the couple manage their anxiety within the marital dyad without involving the child
Prescribe the symptom paradoxically by telling the couple to argue more intensely
Focus only on the son's behavior problems through individual play therapy

questions.explanation: Bowenian theory emphasizes multigenerational transmission of emotional patterns and differentiation levels. Both spouses brought low differentiation from their families of origin (emotional reactivity, cutoff, substance use as anxiety management). Their triangulation of the son is a predictable Bowenian pattern — when the dyad cannot contain its anxiety, a third person is pulled in. Treatment focuses on increasing differentiation (examining one's own emotional reactivity and family-of-origin patterns) and detriangulating the child.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe concepts from systemic and family therapy approaches.
questions.passage: Family therapy approaches share a foundation in general systems theory. [In systems thinking, circular causality replaces linear cause-effect models, recognizing that family members mutually influence each other's behavior]. The concept of the identified patient reflects the systemic view that [the symptomatic family member carries symptoms that reflect dysfunction in the larger family system, not solely individual pathology]. Salvador Minuchin's structural family therapy focuses on reorganizing family structure, and [a key structural concept is that healthy families have clear boundaries that are neither enmeshed nor disengaged]. Murray Bowen proposed that [emotional cutoff from one's family of origin is a healthy resolution of unresolved attachment issues that promotes independence]. Strategic family therapists like Haley are known for [using paradoxical interventions such as prescribing the symptom to make involuntary behavior voluntary]. The narrative therapy approach [positions the therapist as the expert authority who diagnoses the dominant narrative and prescribes the preferred alternative story].

highlightableSegments.text: In systems thinking, circular causality replaces linear cause-effect models, recognizing that family members mutually influence each other's behavior
the symptomatic family member carries symptoms that reflect dysfunction in the larger family system, not solely individual pathology
a key structural concept is that healthy families have clear boundaries that are neither enmeshed nor disengaged
emotional cutoff from one's family of origin is a healthy resolution of unresolved attachment issues that promotes independence
using paradoxical interventions such as prescribing the symptom to make involuntary behavior voluntary
positions the therapist as the expert authority who diagnoses the dominant narrative and prescribes the preferred alternative story

questions.explanation: Circular causality is a foundational systems concept (correct). The IP concept reflects systemic dysfunction (correct). Clear boundaries (neither enmeshed nor disengaged) define healthy structural functioning (correct). Emotional cutoff is NOT healthy in Bowen's theory — it appears to resolve problems but actually increases vulnerability and replicates avoidance patterns (incorrect). Prescribing the symptom is a core strategic technique (correct). Narrative therapy uses a decentered (not expert authority) stance — the client is the primary author of their story, not the therapist (incorrect).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe concepts from the Milan systemic approach and narrative therapy.
questions.passage: The Milan group developed several distinctive therapeutic techniques. [Circular questioning involves asking one family member to comment on the relationship between two other family members, revealing systemic patterns that direct questioning cannot access]. They also developed the concept of [neutrality, which Cecchin later revised to the concept of curiosity, emphasizing the therapist's genuine interest in all perspectives]. In narrative therapy, Michael White was influenced by [Michel Foucault's analysis of power/knowledge and how dominant societal discourses shape what is considered normal and pathological]. A core practice in narrative therapy involves [searching for unique outcomes, which are exceptions to the dominant problem-saturated story that serve as entry points for constructing alternative narratives]. The Milan group also used [positive connotation, which involves criticizing the symptom and attributing negative motivations to each family member's behavior]. Narrative therapists use [therapeutic letters and documents to make therapeutic gains tangible and to serve as external records of the client's preferred story].

highlightableSegments.text: Circular questioning involves asking one family member to comment on the relationship between two other family members, revealing systemic patterns that direct questioning cannot access
neutrality, which Cecchin later revised to the concept of curiosity, emphasizing the therapist's genuine interest in all perspectives
Michel Foucault's analysis of power/knowledge and how dominant societal discourses shape what is considered normal and pathological
searching for unique outcomes, which are exceptions to the dominant problem-saturated story that serve as entry points for constructing alternative narratives
positive connotation, which involves criticizing the symptom and attributing negative motivations to each family member's behavior
therapeutic letters and documents to make therapeutic gains tangible and to serve as external records of the client's preferred story

questions.explanation: Circular questioning reveals systemic patterns through indirect inquiry (correct). Cecchin revised neutrality to curiosity (correct). Foucault's power/knowledge framework deeply influenced White's narrative therapy (correct). Unique outcomes are exceptions to problem stories used to build alternative narratives (correct). Positive connotation does NOT criticize the symptom — it reframes each member's behavior as serving a positive, protective function for the family system (incorrect). Therapeutic letters and documents are signature narrative practices (correct).

questions.stem: Arrange the stages of group development (Tuckman's model) in the correct sequential order.

items.text: Norming (Cohesion) — group identity develops, trust increases, norms are established
Performing (Working) — productive therapeutic work occurs, high cohesion and mutual support
Forming (Orientation) — members are polite, anxious, dependent on the leader
Termination (Adjourning) — consolidation of gains, addressing feelings of loss
Storming (Conflict) — struggles for dominance, resistance to leader and norms
Re-forming — group reconvenes after a break and re-establishes working relationships

questions.explanation: Tuckman's (1965) model of group development progresses through: (1) Forming — polite, anxious, dependent; (2) Storming — conflict, power struggles, testing boundaries; (3) Norming — cohesion develops, trust increases, group identity forms; (4) Performing — productive work, high cohesion; (5) Termination (Adjourning, added later by Tuckman and Jensen) — consolidating gains, processing loss. Re-forming may occur naturally but is not part of the original or expanded model.

questions.stem: Arrange the following structural family therapy interventions in the typical order a therapist would employ them during the course of treatment.

items.text: Restructuring — actively reorganizing the family's transactional patterns through directives and tasks
Joining — accommodating to the family's style and building rapport with each member
Enactment — asking family members to demonstrate their typical interaction patterns in session
Assessing structure — mapping subsystems, boundaries, hierarchies, and coalitions
Boundary making — strengthening or loosening boundaries between subsystems
Consolidation — reinforcing new structural patterns and preparing for termination

questions.explanation: Structural family therapy follows a logical progression: (1) Joining — the therapist must first enter the family system by accommodating to its style; (2) Assessing structure — mapping the family's organizational patterns; (3) Enactment — observing live interactions to confirm the structural assessment; (4) Boundary making — beginning to adjust boundaries between subsystems; (5) Restructuring — actively reorganizing transactional patterns; (6) Consolidation — reinforcing the new structure and preparing for termination.

questions.stem: A researcher studies the effects of structural family therapy on a family's boundary functioning. Enmeshment and disengagement scores are measured at multiple time points during treatment (higher scores indicate more extreme boundary dysfunction).
questions.question: Which conclusion is BEST supported by the data?

options.text: Structural family therapy produced parallel improvements in both enmeshment and disengagement, with gains maintained at follow-up
Reducing enmeshment caused an increase in disengagement, suggesting a compensatory pattern
The father's disengagement score worsened during treatment while enmeshment improved
Both scores returned to pre-treatment levels at the 3-month follow-up, indicating treatment gains were not maintained

questions.explanation: Both enmeshment and disengagement scores decreased substantially and in parallel across treatment (from 8.5/8.0 to 4.1/3.5), and gains were maintained at 3-month follow-up (3.8/3.2). This is consistent with structural family therapy's goal of moving the family toward clear (neither enmeshed nor disengaged) boundaries. The simultaneous improvement in both dimensions supports Minuchin's theory that restructuring the system affects all subsystems, not just the targeted one.

questions.stem: A study examines differentiation of self scores in adults before and after Bowenian family therapy focused on family-of-origin work. Two groups are compared: a Bowenian therapy group and a psychoeducation-only control group.
questions.question: Which interpretation is MOST consistent with the data and Bowenian theory?

options.text: Both groups showed equivalent improvement in differentiation of self over time
Bowenian family-of-origin work produced a steady, progressive increase in differentiation that was substantially greater than psychoeducation alone
Differentiation of self remained stable in both groups, suggesting it is a fixed trait
The psychoeducation group showed faster initial gains but the Bowenian group caught up by Month 12

questions.explanation: The Bowenian therapy group showed a steady, progressive increase in differentiation scores from 42 to 65 (a gain of 23 points), while the control group showed minimal change from 41 to 47 (a gain of 6 points). This supports Bowen's contention that differentiation can be increased through therapeutic work on family-of-origin patterns, and that this is a gradual process requiring sustained effort — consistent with the multigenerational focus of Bowenian therapy.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept or technique according to the family therapy approach it is MOST closely associated with.

items.text: Enmeshment and disengagement as poles of boundary functioning
Genogram mapping multigenerational emotional patterns
Externalization — separating the problem from the person's identity
Unbalancing — deliberately siding with one member to shift the power hierarchy
Differentiation of self and emotional triangles
Definitional ceremonies and outsider witness practices

questions.explanation: Structural therapy (Minuchin): enmeshment/disengagement boundaries and unbalancing techniques to shift family hierarchy. Bowenian therapy: genograms for multigenerational mapping and differentiation of self as the central construct, with triangles as the basic relational unit. Narrative therapy (White & Epston): externalization of problems and definitional ceremonies (outsider witness practices) where an audience reflects on the client's preferred story without interpretation or advice.

questions.stem: Categorize each of Yalom's therapeutic factors according to the phase of group development where it is MOST prominent or relevant.

items.text: Instillation of hope — seeing others improve inspires optimism
Interpersonal learning — gaining insight into one's impact on others through feedback
Existential factors — confronting mortality, responsibility, and meaning
Universality — realizing 'I am not alone' in my struggles
Catharsis — emotional release and expression of feelings in a safe context
Altruism — helping others enhances self-esteem and sense of purpose

questions.explanation: Early group factors include instillation of hope and universality — these develop as members first connect and realize shared experiences. Working group factors include interpersonal learning and catharsis — these require the safety and cohesion built in earlier stages. Termination factors include existential reflection and altruism — as members face ending, they confront existential themes and focus on giving back. Note that these factors can operate across all phases but are most prominent in the phases indicated.
